entry.title: LeetCode 856. Score of Parentheses
entry.content:
Given a balanced parentheses string S, compute the score of the string based on the following rule:

  • () has score 1
  • AB has score A + B, where A and B are balanced parentheses strings.
  • (A) has score 2 * A, where A is a balanced parentheses string.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Example 3:

Example 4:

Note:

  1. S is a balanced parentheses string, containing only ( and ).
  2. 2 <= S.length <= 50

This is not a basic pairing problem.

Watch out for AB and (A) ! ( This is a hint to store the current value and do some adding operations )
entry.summary: Given a balanced parentheses string S, compute the score of the string based on the following rule:

entry.content:
List A Directory With Tree Command

Very helpful, especially when you are working on the dev documentations.

I am a Mac OS user, so brew install tree

And Letâ€™s try out !

Open a Vuetify example component in Codepen.

Modify on Codepen to build a prototype.

entry.title: LeetCode 43. Multiply Strings
entry.content:
Given two non-negative integers num1 and num2 represented as strings, return the product of num1 and num2, also represented as a string.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Note:

  1. The length of both num1 and num2 is < 110.
  2. Both num1 and num2 contain only digits 0-9.
  3. Both num1 and num2 do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself.
  4. You must not use any built-in BigInteger library or convert the inputs to integer directly.
entry.summary: Given two non-negative integers num1 and num2 represented as strings, return the product of

entry.title: R Data Analysis:Where it Pays to Attend College
entry.content:
Huge thanks to WSJ & Kaggle for the dataset : https://www.kaggle.com/wsj/college-salaries

It's summer again. High school kids are facing the question " which college ?". And junior / sophomore college kids are wondering what to choose as major.

So here is my very basic data analysis and hope this can help someone.

Degrees that pay back

When you start ...

MajorStarting Median Salary
44Physician Assistant$74,300.00
9Chemical Engineering$63,200.00
13Computer Engineering$61,400.00
20Electrical Engineering$60,900.00
39Mechanical Engineering$57,900.00
2Aerospace Engineering$57,700.00
31Industrial Engineering$57,700.00
14Computer Science$55,900.00
41Nursing$54,200.00
11Civil Engineering$53,900.00

So if you want a rather high starting salary, you probably should study these majors â¬†ï¸

Midlife expectations

MajorMid-Career Median Salary
18Economics$98,600.00
45Physics$97,300.00
14Computer Science$95,500.00
31Industrial Engineering$94,700.00
39Mechanical Engineering$93,600.00
38Math$92,400.00
44Physician Assistant$91,700.00
11Civil Engineering$90,500.00
15Construction$88,900.00
23Finance$88,300.00

If you want a good salary when you are 30s / 40s, please consider these majors â¬†ï¸

Life-long good salary

Major
1Physician Assistant
2Mechanical Engineering
3Industrial Engineering
4Computer Science
5Civil Engineering

Majors with the highest pay differentials

entry.title: LeetCode 40. Combination Sum II
entry.content:
Given a collection of candidate numbers (candidates) and a target number (target), find all unique combinations in candidates where the candidate numbers sums to target.

Each number in candidates may only be used once in the combination.

Note:

  • All numbers (including target) will be positive integers.
  • The solution set must not contain duplicate combinations.

Example 1:

Example 2:

entry.title: Data Analysis with R: College Admission
entry.content:
Data source : https://www.kaggle.com/samsonqian/college-admissions/data#

Huge thanks to the provider of the dataset ! ğŸ™

As a junior student who wanted to apply for American universities this year yet interrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic, I feel very distressed and lost during the past few months.

I don't know what to do anymore. Everything derails my plans.

So I thought maybe I should get myself together and gap one or two years.

Now I have a new start.

During my gap year at least I can do more research on the admission system (though what I get is undergrad admission data) and prepare myself. That's why I want to write this piece.

Also I want to practice my R skill in the real world ğŸ¥³

The most selective colleges ?

Well, I find some NA so I need to clean the data first.

Filter out all rows has NA :

Be careful about rows and columns in R, never forget the coma !!! ğŸ˜­

Let's check out the top 100 most admission selective colleges :

nameAdmission rate %enroll rate %

Well, not every college on the list is a "traditional prestige university". But many elite universities like Stanford, Harvard, Yale are on the list.

How about the standard test scores?

First, consider the 75th percentile â€”â€” how good are the good students ?

nameper_75 = SAT 75% + ACT 75%
545Harvard University2435
65California Institute of Technology2425

Now we can intersect the two lists above to get the most academic-demanding universities :

Can you graduate ?

It seems that students better push themselves harder. About 35% ~ 60% students cannot graduate in 6 years ğŸ¤”

A lot of prestige universities also received the largest endowments.

Women enrolled ?

We can easily tell from the graph above that women enrollment rate in higher education is definitely improving. Female students make up more than 50% in most colleges.

Diversity ?

Hmmm ... the data range is a little bit drastic this time ...

Because I myself is Asian, I am curious to see what universities have the highest percentage of Asian students :

entry.title: LeetCode 109. Convert Sorted List to Binary Search Tree
entry.content:
Given a singly linked list where elements are sorted in ascending order, convert it to a height balanced BST.

For this problem, a height-balanced binary tree is defined as a binary tree in which the depth of the two subtrees of every node never differ by more than 1.

Example:

entry.title: LeetCode 117. Populating Next Right Pointers in Each Node II
entry.content:
Given a binary tree

Populate each next pointer to point to its next right node. If there is no next right node, the next pointer should be set to NULL.

Initially, all next pointers are set to NULL.

Follow up:

  • You may only use constant extra space.
  • Recursive approach is fine, you may assume implicit stack space does not count as extra space for this problem.

Example 1:

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the given tree is less than 6000.
  • -100 <= node.val <= 100
entry.summary: Given a binary tree

entry.title: LeetCode 116. Populating Next Right Pointers in Each Node
entry.content:
You are given a perfect binary tree where all leaves are on the same level, and every parent has two children. The binary tree has the following definition:

Populate each next pointer to point to its next right node. If there is no next right node, the next pointer should be set to NULL.

Initially, all next pointers are set to NULL.

Follow up:

  • You may only use constant extra space.
  • Recursive approach is fine, you may assume implicit stack space does not count as extra space for this problem.

Example 1:

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the given tree is less than 4096.
  • -1000 <= node.val <= 1000

entry.title: LeetCode 36. Valid Sudoku
entry.content:
Determine if a 9x9 Sudoku board is valid. Only the filled cells need to be validated according to the following rules:

  1. Each row must contain the digits 1-9 without repetition.
  2. Each column must contain the digits 1-9 without repetition.
  3. Each of the 9 3x3 sub-boxes of the grid must contain the digits 1-9 without repetition.

A partially filled sudoku which is valid.

The Sudoku board could be partially filled, where empty cells are filled with the character '.'.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Note:

  • A Sudoku board (partially filled) could be valid but is not necessarily solvable.
  • Only the filled cells need to be validated according to the mentioned rules.
  • The given board contain only digits 1-9 and the character '.'.
  • The given board size is always 9x9.

entry.title: LeetCode 18. 4Sum
entry.content:
Given an array nums of n integers and an integer target, are there elements a, b, c, and d in nums such that a + b + c + d = target? Find all unique quadruplets in the array which gives the sum of target.

Note:

The solution set must not contain duplicate quadruplets.

entry.title: LeetCode 814. Binary Tree Pruning
entry.content:
• We are given the head node root of a binary tree, where additionally every nodeâ€™s value is either a 0 or a 1.

    Return the same tree where every subtree (of the given tree) not containing a 1 has been removed.

    (Recall that the subtree of a node X is X, plus every node that is a descendant of X.)

    Note:

    • The binary tree will have at most 100 nodes.
    • The value of each node will only be 0 or 1.

entry.title: LeetCode 535. Encode and Decode TinyURL
entry.content:
Note: This is a companion problem to the System Design problem: Design TinyURL.

TinyURL is a URL shortening service where you enter a URL such as https://leetcode.com/problems/design-tinyurl and it returns a short URL such as http://tinyurl.com/4e9iAk.

Design the encode and decode methods for the TinyURL service. There is no restriction on how your encode/decode algorithm should work. You just need to ensure that a URL can be encoded to a tiny URL and the tiny URL can be decoded to the original URL.

The accepted version, use current date as the key

The another version can works in the browser:

Why we shorten url?

See this post of Twitter

Why does Twitter have its own link shortener?

  1. Shortened links allow you to share long URLs in a Tweet while maintaining the maximum number of characters for your message.
  2. Our link service measures information such as how many times a link has been clicked, which is an important quality signal in determining how relevant and interesting each Tweet is when compared to similar Tweets.
  3. Having a link shortener protects users from malicious sites that engage in spreading malware, phishing attacks, and other harmful activity. A link converted by Twitterâ€™s link service is checked against a list of potentially dangerous sites. Users are warned with the error message below when clicking on potentially harmful URLs.

If the URL of a site you manage has been flagged, please see this help page about flagged URLs for more information.
